intro: Phyllanthus leucopyrus, commonly known as the white-leaf phyllanthus, is a flowering plant native to Southeast Asia. It belongs to the Euphorbiaceae family and is characterized by its small, clustered flowers and hairy, oval-shaped leaves. The plant typically grows in tropical and subtropical regions, often in moist, shaded environments. Its leaves are usually pale green to white, giving it a distinctive appearance. It is sometimes cultivated for ornamental purposes due to its unique foliage.
